::: questions
-   How do you write a lesson using R Markdown and `{sandpaper}`?
:::

::: objectives
-   Explain how to use markdown with the new lesson template
-   Demonstrate how to include pieces of code, figures, and nested challenge blocks
:::

Tabeller er også datavisualiseringer. Vi er bare en del tættere på data.

Making a table directly is as simple as printing the dataframe:

```{r}
head(mtcars)
```

We can do more advanced stuff working in markdown (as we do here) by using the `kable()` function, especially with the `kableExtra` extension:

```{r}
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
mtcars %>%
  head() %>%
  kable(
    format = "markdown", 
    caption = "Uddrag af `mtcars` dataset"
  ) %>%
  kable_styling(
    bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"),
    full_width = FALSE,
    position = "center"
  ) %>%
  row_spec(0, bold = TRUE, background = "#2E3B4E", color = "white") %>%
  row_spec(1:6, background = c("#F5F5F5", "white"))
```
But it is not very intuitive.
